001package com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.rgb;
002
003import com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.Color;
004import com.badlogic.gdx.utils.NumberUtils;
005import com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.FloatColors;
006import com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.Shaders;
007import com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.ycwcm.Palette;
008
009import java.util.Random;
010
011/**
012 * Contains code for manipulating colors as {@code int}, packed {@code float}, and {@link Color} values in the RGB
013 * color space. All of these colors have an alpha channel as well as red, green, and blue; the package name isn't
014 * "rgba" because "ycwcm" and "ipt" don't mention alpha either and they also have that channel. RGB is the standard mode
015 * for colors in libGDX, and conversions to and from RGB are in the ColorTools classes for each other color space (like
016 * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.ipt.ColorTools#fromRGBA(float, float, float, float)} and
017 * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.ycwcm.ColorTools#toRGBA(float)}).
018 */
019public class ColorTools {
020        /**
021         * No need to instantiate.
022         */
023        private ColorTools(){
024        }
025        /**
026         * Gets a packed float representation of a color given as 4 float components, here, R (red), G (green), B (blue),
027         * and A (alpha or opacity). As long as you use a batch with {@link Shaders#fragmentShaderRGBA} or
028         * {@link Shaders#fragmentShaderGammaRGBA} as its shader, colors passed with
029         * {@link com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.Batch#setPackedColor(float)} will be interpreted as RGB. All channels range
030         * from 0.0 to 1.0, inclusive. Alpha is the multiplicative opacity of the color.
031         * <br>
032         * This method bit-masks the resulting color's byte values, so any values can technically be given to this as red,
033         * green, and blue, but they will only be reversible from the returned float color to the original R, G, and B
034         * values if the original values were in the range that {@link #red(float)}, {@link #green(float)}, and
035         * {@link #blue(float)} return.
036         *
037         * @param red       0f to 1f, red channel
038         * @param green     0f to 1f, green channel
039         * @param blue      0f to 1f, blue channel
040         * @param alpha     0f to 1f, 0f makes the color transparent and 1f makes it opaque
041         * @return a float encoding a color with the given properties
042         */
043        public static float rgb(float red, float green, float blue, float alpha) {
044                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (alpha * 255) << 24 & 0xFE000000) | ((int) (blue * 255) << 16 & 0xFF0000)
045                                | ((int) (green * 255) << 8 & 0xFF00) | ((int) (red * 255) & 0xFF));
046        }
047
048        /**
049         * Writes an RGB-format packed float color (the format produced by {@link ColorTools#rgb(float, float, float, float)})
050         * into an RGBA8888 Color as used by libGDX (called {@code editing}).
051         * @param editing a libGDX color that will be filled in-place with an RGBA conversion of {@code packed}
052         * @param packed a packed float color, as produced by {@link ColorTools#rgb(float, float, float, float)}
053         * @return an RGBA8888 int color
054         */
055        public static Color toColor(Color editing, final float packed)
056        {
057                Color.abgr8888ToColor(editing, packed);
058                return editing;
059        }
060        /**
061         * Converts a packed float color in the format produced by {@link #rgb(float, float, float, float)} to an
062         * RGBA8888 int. This format of int can be used with Pixmap and in some other places in libGDX.
063         * @param packed a packed float color, as produced by {@link #rgb(float, float, float, float)}
064         * @return an RGBA8888 int color
065         */
066        public static int toRGBA8888(final float packed) {
067                return Integer.reverseBytes(NumberUtils.floatToIntColor(packed));
068        }
069
070        /**
071         * Takes a color encoded as an RGBA8888 int and converts to a packed float in the RGB format this uses.
072         * @param rgba an int with the channels (in order) red, green, blue, alpha; should have 8 bits per channel
073         * @return a packed float as RGB, which this class can use
074         */
075        public static float fromRGBA8888(final int rgba) {
076                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(Integer.reverseBytes(rgba) & 0xFEFFFFFF);
077        }
078
079        /**
080         * Takes a libGDX Color that uses RGBA8888 channels and converts to a packed float in the RGB format this uses.
081         * @param color a libGDX RGBA8888 Color
082         * @return a packed float as RGB, which this class can use
083         */
084        public static float fromColor(final Color color) {
085                return color.toFloatBits();
086        }
087
088        /**
089         * Takes RGBA components from 0.0 to 1.0 each and converts to a packed float in the RGBA format this uses.
090         * @param r red, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
091         * @param g green, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
092         * @param b blue, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
093         * @param a alpha, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
094         * @return a packed float as RGBA, which this class can use
095         */
096        public static float fromRGBA(final float r, final float g, final float b, final float a) {
097                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
098                                          Math.min(Math.max((int)(r * 255.999f), 0), 255)
099                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)(g * 255.999f), 0), 255) << 8
100                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)(b * 255.999f), 0), 255) << 16
101                                                | ((int)(a * 255f) << 24 & 0xFE000000));
102        }
103
104        /**
105         * Gets the red channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
106         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #rgb(float, float, float, float)}
107         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the red channel value of the given encoded color
108         */
109        public static int redInt(final float encoded) {
110                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
111                return (decoded & 0xff);
112        }
113
114        /**
115         * Gets the green channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
116         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #rgb(float, float, float, float)}
117         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the green channel value of the given encoded color
118         */
119        public static int greenInt(final float encoded) {
120                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
121                return (decoded >>> 8 & 0xff);
122        }
123
124        /**
125         * Gets the blue channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
126         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #rgb(float, float, float, float)}
127         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the blue channel value of the given encoded color
128         */
129        public static int blueInt(final float encoded) {
130                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
131                return  (decoded >>> 16 & 0xff);
132        }
133
134        /**
135         * Gets the alpha channel value of the given encoded color, as an even int ranging from 0 to 254, inclusive. Because
136         * of how alpha is stored in libGDX, no odd-number values are possible for alpha.
137         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #rgb(float, float, float, float)}
138         * @return an even int from 0 to 254, inclusive, representing the alpha channel value of the given encoded color
139         */
140        public static int alphaInt(final float encoded) {
141                return (NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xfe000000) >>> 24;
142        }
143
144        /**
145         * Gets the red channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
146         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #rgb(float, float, float, float)}
147         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the red channel value of the given encoded color
148         */
149        public static float red(final float encoded) {
150                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
151                return  (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
152        }
153
154        /**
155         * Gets the green channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
156         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #rgb(float, float, float, float)}
157         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the green channel value of the given encoded color
158         */
159        public static float green(final float encoded) {
160                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
161                return  (decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) / 255f;
162        }
163
164        /**
165         * Gets the blue channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
166         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #rgb(float, float, float, float)}
167         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the blue channel value of the given encoded color
168         */
169        public static float blue(final float encoded) {
170                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
171                return  (decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) / 255f;
172        }
173
174        /**
175         * Gets the alpha channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
176         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #rgb(float, float, float, float)}
177         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the alpha channel value of the given encoded color
178         */
179        public static float alpha(final float encoded) {
180                return ((NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xfe000000) >>> 24) * 0x1.020408p-8f;
181        }
182
183        /**
184         * Gets a color as an RGBA packed float given floats representing hue, saturation, lightness, and opacity.
185         * All parameters should normally be between 0 and 1 inclusive, though any hue is tolerated (precision loss may
186         * affect the color if the hue is too large). A hue of 0 is red, progressively higher hue values go to orange,
187         * yellow, green, blue, and purple before wrapping around to red as it approaches 1. A saturation of 0 is grayscale,
188         * a saturation of 1 is brightly colored, and values close to 1 will usually appear more distinct than values close
189         * to 0, especially if the hue is different. A lightness of 0.001f or less is always black (also using a shortcut if
190         * this is the case, respecting opacity), while a lightness of 1f is white. Very bright colors are mostly in a band
191         * of high-saturation where lightness is 0.5f.
192         *
193         * @param hue        0f to 1f, color wheel position
194         * @param saturation 0f to 1f, 0f is grayscale and 1f is brightly colored
195         * @param lightness  0f to 1f, 0f is black and 1f is white
196         * @param opacity    0f to 1f, 0f is fully transparent and 1f is opaque
197         * @return a float encoding a color with the given properties
198         */
199        public static float floatGetHSL(float hue, float saturation, float lightness, float opacity) {
200                if (lightness <= 0.001f) {
201                        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat((((int) (opacity * 255f) << 24) & 0xFE000000) | 0x7F7F00);
202                } else {
203                        return FloatColors.hsl2rgb(hue, saturation, lightness, opacity);
204                }
205        }
206
207        /**
208         * Gets the saturation of the given encoded color, as a float ranging from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
209         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #rgb(float, float, float, float)}
210         * @return the saturation of the color from 0.0 (a grayscale color; inclusive) to 1.0 (a bright color, inclusive)
211         */
212        public static float saturation(final float encoded) {
213                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
214                final float r = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
215                final float g = (decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) / 255f;
216                final float b = (decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) / 255f;
217                float x, y, w;
218                if(g < b) {
219                        x = b;
220                        y = g;
221                }
222                else {
223                        x = g;
224                        y = b;
225                }
226                if(r < x) {
227                        w = r;
228                }
229                else {
230                        w = x;
231                        x = r;
232                }
233                return x - Math.min(w, y);
234//              float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
235//              float li = x * (1f - 0.5f * d / (x + 1e-10f));
236//              return (x - li); // (Math.min(li, 1f - li) + 1e-10f);
237        }
238
239        public static float lightness(final float encoded) {
240                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
241                final float r = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
242                final float g = (decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) / 255f;
243                final float b = (decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) / 255f;
244                float x, y, w;
245                if(g < b) {
246                        x = b;
247                        y = g;
248                }
249                else {
250                        x = g;
251                        y = b;
252                }
253                if(r < x) {
254                        w = r;
255                }
256                else {
257                        w = x;
258                        x = r;
259                }
260                float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
261                return x * (1f - 0.5f * d / (x + 1e-10f));
262        }
263
264        /**
265         * Gets the hue of the given encoded color, as a float from 0f (inclusive, red and approaching orange if increased)
266         * to 1f (exclusive, red and approaching purple if decreased).
267         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #rgb(float, float, float, float)}
268         * @return The hue of the color from 0.0 (red, inclusive) towards orange, then yellow, and
269         * eventually to purple before looping back to almost the same red (1.0, exclusive)
270         */
271        public static float hue(final float encoded) {
272                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
273                final float r = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
274                final float g = (decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) / 255f;
275                final float b = (decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) / 255f;
276                float x, y, z, w;
277                if(g < b) {
278                        x = b;
279                        y = g;
280                        z = -1f;
281                        w = 2f / 3f;
282                }
283                else {
284                        x = g;
285                        y = b;
286                        z = 0f;
287                        w = -1f / 3f;
288                }
289                if(r < x) {
290                        z = w;
291                        w = r;
292                }
293                else {
294                        w = x;
295                        x = r;
296                }
297                float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
298                return Math.abs(z + (w - y) / (6f * d + 1e-10f));
299        }
300
301        /**
302         * Gets a variation on the packed float color basis as another packed float that has its hue, saturation, lightness,
303         * and opacity adjusted by the specified amounts. Note that this edits the color in HSL space, not RGB! Takes
304         * floats representing the amounts of change to apply to hue, saturation, lightness, and opacity; these can be
305         * between -1f and 1f. Returns a float that can be used as a packed or encoded color with methods like
306         * {@link com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.Batch#setPackedColor(float)}. The float is likely to be different than the
307         * result of {@link #rgb(float, float, float, float)} unless hue, saturation, lightness, and opacity are all 0. This
308         * won't allocate any objects.
309         * <br>
310         * The parameters this takes all specify additive changes for a color component, clamping the final values so they
311         * can't go above 1 or below 0, with an exception for hue, which can rotate around if lower or higher hues would be
312         * used. As an example, if you give this 0.4f for saturation, and the current color has saturation 0.7f, then the
313         * resulting color will have 1f for saturation. If you gave this -0.1f for saturation and the current color again
314         * has saturation 0.7f, then resulting color will have 0.6f for saturation.
315         *
316         * @param basis      a packed float color that will be used as the starting point to make the next color
317         * @param hue        -1f to 1f, the hue change that can be applied to the new float color (not clamped, wraps)
318         * @param saturation -1f to 1f, the saturation change that can be applied to the new float color
319         * @param light      -1f to 1f, the light/brightness change that can be applied to the new float color
320         * @param opacity    -1f to 1f, the opacity/alpha change that can be applied to the new float color
321         * @return a float encoding a variation of basis with the given changes
322         */
323        public static float toEditedFloat(float basis, float hue, float saturation, float light, float opacity) {
324                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(basis);
325                opacity = Math.min(Math.max(opacity + (decoded >>> 24 & 0xfe) * 0x1.020408p-8f, 0f), 1f);
326                final float r = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
327                final float g = (decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) / 255f;
328                final float b = (decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) / 255f;
329                float x, y, z, w;
330                if(g < b) {
331                        x = b;
332                        y = g;
333                        z = -1f;
334                        w = 2f / 3f;
335                }
336                else {
337                        x = g;
338                        y = b;
339                        z = 0f;
340                        w = -1f / 3f;
341                }
342                if(r < x) {
343                        z = w;
344                        w = r;
345                }
346                else {
347                        w = x;
348                        x = r;
349                }
350                final float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
351                light = Math.min(Math.max(x * (1f - 0.5f * d / (x + 1e-10f)) + light, 0f), 1f);
352                hue += Math.abs(z + (w - y) / (6f * d + 1e-10f)) + 1f;
353                saturation += x - Math.min(w, y);
354                return FloatColors.hsl2rgb(hue - (int)hue, Math.min(Math.max(saturation, 0f), 1f), light, opacity);
355        }
356
357        /**
358         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards white by change. While change should be between 0f (return
359         * start as-is) and 1f (return white), start should be a packed color, as from
360         * {@link #rgb(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
361         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
362         * white. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and both chroma of start as-is.
363         * @see #darken(float, float) the counterpart method that darkens a float color
364         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
365         * @param change how much to go from start toward white, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to white
366         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and white
367         */
368        public static float lighten(final float start, final float change) {
369                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), r = s & 0xFF, g = s >>> 8 & 0xFF, b = s >>> 16 & 0xFF,
370                                a = s & 0xFE000000;
371                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
372                                ((int) (r + (0xFF - r) * change) & 0xFF) |
373                                ((int) (g + (0xFF - g) * change) & 0xFF) << 8 |
374                                ((int) (b + (0xFF - b) * change) & 0xFF) << 16 |
375                                a);
376        }
377
378        /**
379         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards black by change. While change should be between 0f (return
380         * start as-is) and 1f (return black), start should be a packed color, as from
381         * {@link #rgb(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
382         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
383         * black. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and both chroma of start as-is.
384         * @see #lighten(float, float) the counterpart method that lightens a float color
385         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
386         * @param change how much to go from start toward black, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to black
387         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and black
388         */
389        public static float darken(final float start, final float change) {
390                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), r = s & 0xFF, g = s >>> 8 & 0xFF, b = s >>> 16 & 0xFF,
391                                a = s & 0xFE000000;
392                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
393                                ((int) (r * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) |
394                                ((int) (g * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) << 8 |
395                                ((int) (b * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) << 16 |
396                                a);
397        }
398        /**
399         * Interpolates from the packed float color start to increase its red channel by change.
400         * While change must be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return maximum red), start should be a packed
401         * color, as from {@link #rgb(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary
402         * Colors, and is a little more efficient and clear than using
403         * {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards a more-red color. Unlike
404         * {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the other channels of start as-is.
405         * @see #lowerB(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color less red
406         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
407         * @param change how much to change start to a more-red color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means more red
408         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a more red color
409         */
410        public static float raiseR(final float start, final float change) {
411                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), t = s & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFFFF00;
412                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (t + (0xFF - t) * change) & 0xFF) | other);
413        }
414
415        /**
416         * Interpolates from the packed float color start to decrease its red channel by change.
417         * While change must be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return minimum red), start should be a packed
418         * color, as from {@link #rgb(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary
419         * Colors, and is a little more efficient and clear than using
420         * {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards a less-red color. Unlike
421         * {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the other channels of start as-is.
422         * @see #raiseB(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more red
423         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
424         * @param change how much to change start to a less-red color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means less red
425         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a less red color
426         */
427        public static float lowerR(final float start, final float change) {
428                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), t = s & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFFFF00;
429                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (t * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) | other);
430        }
431
432        /**
433         * Interpolates from the packed float color start to increase its green channel by change.
434         * While change must be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return maximum green), start should be a packed
435         * color, as from {@link #rgb(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary
436         * Colors, and is a little more efficient and clear than using
437         * {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards a more-green color. Unlike
438         * {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the other channels of start as-is.
439         * @see #lowerB(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color less green
440         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
441         * @param change how much to change start to a more-green color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means more green
442         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a more green color
443         */
444        public static float raiseG(final float start, final float change) {
445                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), t = s >>> 8 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFF00FF;
446                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (t + (0xFF - t) * change) << 8 & 0xFF00) | other);
447        }
448
449        /**
450         * Interpolates from the packed float color start to decrease its green channel by change.
451         * While change must be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return minimum green), start should be a packed
452         * color, as from {@link #rgb(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary
453         * Colors, and is a little more efficient and clear than using
454         * {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards a less-green color. Unlike
455         * {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the other channels of start as-is.
456         * @see #raiseB(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more green
457         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
458         * @param change how much to change start to a less-green color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means less green
459         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a less green color
460         */
461        public static float lowerG(final float start, final float change) {
462                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), t = s >>> 8 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFF00FF;
463                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (t * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) << 8 | other);
464        }
465
466        /**
467         * Interpolates from the packed float color start to increase its blue channel by change.
468         * While change must be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return maximum blue), start should be a packed
469         * color, as from {@link #rgb(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary
470         * Colors, and is a little more efficient and clear than using
471         * {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards a more-blue color. Unlike
472         * {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the other channels of start as-is.
473         * @see #lowerB(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color less blue
474         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
475         * @param change how much to change start to a more-blue color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means more blue
476         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a more blue color
477         */
478        public static float raiseB(final float start, final float change) {
479                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), t = s >>> 16 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFE00FFFF;
480                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (t + (0xFF - t) * change) << 16 & 0xFF0000) | other);
481        }
482
483        /**
484         * Interpolates from the packed float color start to decrease its blue channel by change.
485         * While change must be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return minimum blue), start should be a packed
486         * color, as from {@link #rgb(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary
487         * Colors, and is a little more efficient and clear than using
488         * {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards a less-blue color. Unlike
489         * {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the other channels of start as-is.
490         * @see #raiseB(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more blue
491         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
492         * @param change how much to change start to a less-blue color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means less blue
493         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a less blue color
494         */
495        public static float lowerB(final float start, final float change) {
496                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), t = s >>> 16 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFE00FFFF;
497                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (t * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) << 16 | other);
498        }
499
500        /**
501         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards that color made opaque by change. While change should be
502         * between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return start with full alpha), start should be a packed color, as from
503         * {@link #rgb(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
504         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
505         * transparent. This won't change the red, green, or blue of the color.
506         * @see #fade(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more translucent
507         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
508         * @param change how much to go from start toward opaque, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to opaque
509         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and its opaque version
510         */
511        public static float blot(final float start, final float change) {
512                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), opacity = s >>> 24 & 0xFE, other = s & 0x00FFFFFF;
513                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (opacity + (0xFE - opacity) * change) & 0xFE) << 24 | other);
514        }
515
516        /**
517         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards transparent by change. While change should be between 0
518         * (return start as-is) and 1f (return the color with 0 alpha), start should be a packed color, as from
519         * {@link #rgb(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors,
520         * and is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
521         * transparent. This won't change the red, green, or blue of the color.
522         * @see #blot(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more opaque
523         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
524         * @param change how much to go from start toward transparent, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to transparent
525         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and transparent
526         */
527        public static float fade(final float start, final float change) {
528                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), opacity = s & 0xFE, other = s & 0x00FFFFFF;
529                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (opacity * (1f - change)) & 0xFE) << 24 | other);
530        }
531
532        /**
533         * Given a packed float RGBA color {@code mainColor} and another RGBA color that it should be made to contrast with,
534         * gets a packed float RGBA color with roughly inverted lightness (how the Oklab color space interprets it), but the
535         * same general hue and saturation unless the lightness gets too close to white or black. This won't ever produce
536         * black or other very dark colors, and also has a gap in the range it produces for lightness values between 0.5 and
537         * 0.55. That allows most of the colors this method produces to contrast well as a foreground when displayed on a
538         * background of {@code contrastingColor}, or vice versa. This will leave the lightness unchanged if the
539         * hue/saturation of the contrastingColor and those of the mainColor are already very different. This has nothing to
540         * do with the contrast channel of the tweak in ColorfulBatch; where that part of the tweak can make too-similar
541         * lightness values further apart by just a little, this makes a modification on {@code mainColor} to maximize its
542         * lightness difference from {@code contrastingColor} without losing its other qualities.
543         * @param mainColor a packed float color, as produced by {@link #rgb(float, float, float, float)}; this is the color that will be adjusted
544         * @param contrastingColor a packed float color, as produced by {@link #rgb(float, float, float, float)}; the adjusted mainColor will contrast with this
545         * @return a different RGBA packed float color, based on mainColor but with potentially very different lightness
546         */
547        public static float inverseLightness(final float mainColor, final float contrastingColor)
548        {
549                return com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.oklab.ColorTools.toRGBA(
550                                com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.oklab.ColorTools.inverseLightness(
551                                                com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.oklab.ColorTools.fromRGBA(mainColor),
552                                                com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.oklab.ColorTools.fromRGBA(contrastingColor)));
553        }
554
555        /**
556         * Given a packed float RGBA color {@code mainColor} and another RGBA color that it should be made to contrast
557         * with, gets a packed float RGBA color with lightness that should be quite different from
558         * {@code contrastingColor}'s lightness, but the same chromatic channels and opacity. This allows most of the colors
559         * this method produces to contrast well as a foreground when displayed on a background of {@code contrastingColor},
560         * or vice versa. This goes through Oklab as an intermediate step, so lightness is in terms of Oklab's L channel.
561         * <br>
562         * This is similar to {@link #inverseLightness(float, float)}, but is considerably simpler, and this method will
563         * change the lightness of mainColor when the two given colors have close lightness but distant chroma. Because it
564         * averages the original lightness of mainColor with the modified one, this tends to produce softer color changes.
565         * @param mainColor a packed RGBA float color; this is the color that will be adjusted
566         * @param contrastingColor a packed RGBA float color; the adjusted mainColor will contrast with the lightness of this
567         * @return a different packed RGBA float color, based on mainColor but typically with different lightness
568         */
569        public static float differentiateLightness(final float mainColor, final float contrastingColor)
570        {
571                final int main = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.oklab.ColorTools.fromRGBA(mainColor)),
572                                contrast = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.oklab.ColorTools.fromRGBA(contrastingColor));
573                return com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.oklab.ColorTools.toRGBA(NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat((main & 0xFEFFFF00) | (contrast + 128 & 0xFF) + (main & 0xFF) >>> 1));
574        }
575
576        /**
577         * Pretty simple; adds 0.5 to the given color's lightness (calculated by converting it to Oklab internally) and
578         * wraps it around if it would go above 1.0, then averages that with the original lightness. This means light colors
579         * become darker, and dark colors become lighter, with almost all results in the middle-range of possible lightness.
580         * @param mainColor a packed RGBA float color
581         * @return a different packed RGBA float color, with its lightness channel changed and limited to the correct gamut
582         */
583        public static float offsetLightness(final float mainColor) {
584                final int oklab = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(mainColor);
585                return com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.oklab.ColorTools.toRGBA(NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat((oklab & 0xFEFFFF00) | (oklab + 128 & 0xFF) + (oklab & 0xFF) >>> 1));
586        }
587
588        /**
589         * Makes the additive RGBA color stored in {@code color} cause less of a change when used as a tint, as if it were
590         * mixed with neutral gray. When {@code fraction} is 1.0, this returns color unchanged; when fraction is 0.0, it
591         * returns {@link Palette#GRAY}, and when it is in-between 0.0 and 1.0 it returns something between the two. This is
592         * meant for things like area of effect abilities that make smaller color changes toward their periphery.
593         * @param color a color that should have its tinting effect potentially weakened
594         * @param fraction how much of {@code color} should be kept, from 0.0 to 1.0
595         * @return an RGBA float color between gray and {@code color}
596         */
597        public static float lessenChange(final float color, float fraction) {
598                final int e = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(color),
599                                rs = 0x80, gs = 0x80, bs = 0x80, as = 0xFE,
600                                re = (e & 0xFF), ge = (e >>> 8) & 0xFF, be = (e >>> 16) & 0xFF, ae = e >>> 24 & 0xFE;
601                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
602                                  ((int) (rs + fraction * (re - rs)) & 0xFF)
603                                | ((int) (gs + fraction * (ge - gs)) & 0xFF) << 8
604                                | ((int) (bs + fraction * (be - bs)) & 0xFF) << 16
605                                                  | (ae << 24));
606        }
607
608        /**
609         * Given a packed float RGB color, this edits its red, green, blue, and alpha channels by adding the corresponding
610         * "add" parameter and then clamping. Each value is considered in the 0 to 1 range. This returns a different float
611         * value (of course, the given float can't be edited in-place). You can give a value of 0 for any "add" parameter
612         * you want to stay unchanged.
613         * @param encoded a packed float RGB color
614         * @param addR how much to add to the R channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
615         * @param addG how much to add to the G channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
616         * @param addB how much to add to the B channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
617         * @param addAlpha how much to add to the alpha channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
618         * @return a packed float RGB color with the requested edits applied to {@code encoded}
619         */
620        public static float editRGB(float encoded, float addR, float addG, float addB, float addAlpha){
621                return editRGB(encoded, addR, addG, addB, addAlpha, 1f, 1f, 1f, 1f);
622        }
623
624        /**
625         * Given a packed float RGB color, this edits its red, green, blue, and alpha channels by first multiplying each
626         * channel by the corresponding "mul" parameter and then adding the corresponding "add" parameter, before clamping.
627         * This means the red value {@code R} (which is considered in the 0 to 1 range) is multiplied by {@code mulR}, then
628         * has {@code addR} added, and then is clamped to the normal range for R (0 to 1). This returns a different float
629         * value (of course, the given float can't be edited in-place). You can give a value of 0 for any "add" parameter
630         * you want to stay unchanged, or a value of 1 for any "mul" parameter that shouldn't change.
631         * @param encoded a packed float RGB color
632         * @param addR how much to add to the R channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
633         * @param addG how much to add to the G channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
634         * @param addB how much to add to the B channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
635         * @param addAlpha how much to add to the alpha channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
636         * @param mulR how much to multiply the R channel by; should be non-negative
637         * @param mulG how much to multiply the G channel by; should be non-negative
638         * @param mulB how much to multiply the B channel by; should be non-negative
639         * @param mulAlpha how much to multiply the alpha channel by; should be non-negative
640         * @return a packed float RGB color with the requested edits applied to {@code encoded}
641         */
642        public static float editRGB(float encoded, float addR, float addG, float addB, float addAlpha,
643                                                                float mulR, float mulG, float mulB, float mulAlpha){
644                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded), r = s & 0xFF, g = s >>> 8 & 0xFF, b = s >>> 16 & 0xFF,
645                                a = s >>> 25;
646                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
647                                Math.max(0, Math.min(255, (int) (r * mulR + addR * 255.999f))) |
648                                Math.max(0, Math.min(255, (int) (g * mulG + addG * 255.999f))) << 8 |
649                                Math.max(0, Math.min(255, (int) (b * mulB + addB * 255.999f))) << 16 |
650                                Math.max(0, Math.min(127, (int) (a * mulAlpha + addAlpha * 127.999f))) << 25);
651        }
652
653        /**
654         * Makes a quasi-randomly-edited variant on the given {@code color}, allowing typically a small amount of
655         * {@code variance} (such as 0.05 to 0.25) between the given color and what this can return. The {@code seed} should
656         * be different each time this is called, and can be obtained from a random number generator to make the colors more
657         * random, or can be incremented on each call. If the seed is only incremented or decremented, then this shouldn't
658         * produce two similar colors in a row unless variance is very small. The variance affects the R, G, and B of the
659         * generated color equally, and each of those channels can go up or down by the given variance as long as the total
660         * distance isn't greater than the variance.
661         * @param color a packed float color, as produced by {@link #rgb(float, float, float, float)}
662         * @param seed a long seed that should be different on each call; should not be 0
663         * @param variance max amount of difference between the given color and the generated color; always less than 1
664         * @return a generated packed float color that should be at least somewhat different from {@code color}
665         */
666        public static float randomEdit(final float color, long seed, final float variance) {
667                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(color);
668                final float r = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
669                final float g = (decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) / 255f;
670                final float b = (decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) / 255f;
671                final float limit = variance * variance;
672                float dist, x, y, z;
673                for (int j = 0; j < 50; j++) {
674                        x = (((seed * 0xD1B54A32D192ED03L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
675                        y = (((seed * 0xABC98388FB8FAC03L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
676                        z = (((seed * 0x8CB92BA72F3D8DD7L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
677                        seed += 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L;
678                        dist = x * x + y * y + z * z;
679                        x += r;
680                        y += g;
681                        z += b;
682                        if(dist <= limit)
683                                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat((decoded & 0xFE000000) | ((int)(z * 255.999f) << 16 & 0xFF0000)
684                                        | ((int)(y * 255.999f) << 8 & 0xFF00) | (int)(x * 255.999f));
685                }
686                return color;
687        }
688
689        /**
690         * Produces a random packed float color that is always opaque and should be uniformly distributed.
691         * @param random a Random object (or preferably a subclass of Random, like {@link com.badlogic.gdx.math.RandomXS128})
692         * @return a packed float color that is always opaque
693         */
694        public static float randomColor(Random random) {
695                final float r = random.nextFloat(), g = random.nextFloat(), b = random.nextFloat();
696                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(0xFE000000
697                                | ((int) (b * 256f) << 16 & 0xFF0000)
698                                | ((int) (g * 256f) << 8 & 0xFF00)
699                                | ((int) (r * 256f) & 0xFF));
700        }
701
702        /**
703         * Limited-use; like {@link #randomColor(Random)} but for cases where you already have three floats (r, g, and b)
704         * distributed how you want. This can be somewhat useful if you are using a "subrandom" or "quasi-random" sequence,
705         * like the Halton, Sobol, or R3 sequences, to get 3D points and map them to colors. It can also be useful if you
706         * want to randomly generate the RGB channels yourself and track the values produced, as you would if you wanted to
707         * avoid generating too many colors with high blue, for instance.
708         * @param r red value to use; will be clamped between 0 and 1
709         * @param g green value to use; will be clamped between 0 and 1
710         * @param b blue value to use; will be clamped between 0 and 1
711         * @return a packed float color that is always opaque
712         */
713        public static float subrandomColor(float r, float g, float b) {
714                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(0xFE000000
715                                | ((int) Math.min(Math.max(b * 256f, 0), 255.999f) << 16 & 0xFF0000)
716                                | ((int) Math.min(Math.max(g * 256f, 0), 255.999f) << 8 & 0xFF00)
717                                | ((int) Math.min(Math.max(r * 256f, 0), 255.999f) & 0xFF));
718        }
719}
